articles.name: Microsoft Teams Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.title: Microsoft Teams Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.body:
In this guide, you’ll learn how to integrate Microsoft Teams with SecurityCoach. You can use Microsoft Teams to send SecurityTips to your users when risky activity is detected on their devices.

For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual. If you're looking for information about setting up security vendor integrations that will detect risky activity on your users' devices, see our vendor integration guides.

Note:Microsoft Government Community Cloud (GCC) and Government Community Cloud High (GCC-High) integrations are not supported at this time.

Setting Up the Integration

To set up this integration, you must upload a SecurityCoach bot to Microsoft Teams. Depending on your organization's settings, you may also need to edit permissions to allow the application in Microsoft Teams.

For more information, read the subsections below.

Uploading the SecurityCoach Bot

To add the SecurityCoach application to Microsoft Teams, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console.
  2. Navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup.
  3. From the menu on the left side of the page, select Delivery Setup.
  4. Click Microsoft Teams.

  5. Enter a name for the bot in the Bot Name (required) field.

    Note:The default name is KB4 Security Awareness. You can enter a different name for your bot in the Bot Name field.
  6. Click Upload Bot. When you click this button, a Microsoft 365 login page will display.
  7. Log in to your Microsoft 365 admin account. A new Permissions requested page will load after successful login.

    1. Sign you in and read your profile: This permission is used to verify you have the correct admin permissions to manage the bot.
    2. Submit application packages to your organization’s catalog and cancel pending submissions: This permission is used to send data from SecurityCoach to the app catalog so that the bot can be deployed.
    3. Read and write to all app catalogs: This permission allows you to update and delete the bot from your SecurityCoach console.
    4. Maintain access to data you have given it access to: This permission allows the bot to maintain the other permissions until you delete the integration.
  8. Select the Consent on behalf of your organization check box, then click Accept at the bottom of the page.
  9. Back on the Microsoft Teams Setup page in SecurityCoach, click Review Permission. When you click this button, a Microsoft 365 login page will display.
  10. Log in to your Microsoft 365 admin account. A second Permissions requested page will load after successful login.

    1. Read all app catalogs: This permission confirms that the bot was successfully uploaded.
    2. Read all users’ full profiles: This permission allows the bot to synchronize your selected Microsoft Teams users with SecurityCoach.
    3. Read directory data: This permission locates your Microsoft Teams users and installs the bot for them.
    4. Allow the app to manage itself for all users: This permission allows the bot to install, update, and uninstall itself for your users.
    5. Allow the Teams app to manage itself for all teams: This permission allows the bot to install, update, and uninstall itself for your teams.
  11. Click Accept at the bottom of the page.
  12. Back on the Microsoft Teams Setup page in SecurityCoach, enable the SecurityCoach bot for Specific Teams or All Teams Users in Microsoft Teams. If you are adding specific teams, select Specific Teams, choose your teams from the drop-down menu, then click Add Teams to confirm. If you are adding all Teams users, click All Teams Users, then click Add All Users to confirm.

  13. If your organization allows only specific applications in Microsoft Teams or if you encounter a policy permissions issue, continue to the steps in the Managing Setup Policies in Microsoft Teams section below. If your organization allows any applications in Microsoft Teams, continue to the Using the Integration section below.

The Bot Has Been Blocked or Removed

If you encounter the error The bot has been blocked or removed, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft Teams admin center.
  2. Use the sidebar to navigate to the Teams app tab > Manage apps subtab.
  3. Look for the KB4 Security Awareness bot in the Manage apps subtab.
    Important:The default name for the bot is KB4 Security Awareness. If you did not use the default name while following the steps in the Uploading the SecurityCoach Bot section, search for your custom bot name instead.
    • If the bot is present, permissions are still loading. Wait one minute and then refresh the Microsoft Teams setup page in your SecurityCoach console. If this does not resolve the error, follow the steps in the Deleting the Integration section and then set up the integration again.
    • If the bot is not present, the bot was removed in Microsoft Teams. Follow the steps in Deleting the Integration section, then set up the integration again.

The SecurityCoach Bot Could Not Be Installed

If any users experience an error during syncing, you can click Generate CSV to download a list of users that were not synced and the error message for each user.

Managing Setup Policies in Microsoft Teams

If your organization manages how apps are made available to users with the Teams app, you’ll need to allow the SecurityCoach application.

To allow the SecurityCoach application, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft Teams admin center.
  2. In the sidebar on the left side, click Teams apps to expand a drop-down menu.

  3. Click Setup policies from the drop-down menu.

  4. On the App setup policies page, you will need to click the name of the policy your team is under. If your team is under the default global policy, click Global (Org-wide default). If your team is under a custom policy, click that custom policy’s name.

  5. In the following Global (Org-wide default) or custom policy page, click Add apps. A new sidebar will open on the right side of the screen.

  6. Use the search bar in the sidebar on the right side of the screen to search for the KB4 Security Awareness app.
    Important:The default name for the app is KB4 Security Awareness. If you did not use the default name while Uploading the SecurityCoach Bot, search for your custom bot name instead.

  7. KB4 Security Awareness will appear in a drop-down menu underneath the search bar.

  8. Click Select to the right of KB4 Security Awareness.

  9. Once the app is selected, click Add below.

  10. The KB4 Security Awareness app will now show under Installed apps.

Once the KB4 Security Awareness app is installed, allow up to 12 hours for changes to apply in the Microsoft admin center.

Note:If the KB4 Security Awareness app takes longer than 12 hours to deploy, a conflicting policy may be preventing deployment. For assistance with conflicting custom policies in the Microsoft admin center, please contact KnowBe4 support at support.knowbe4.com.

Once changes have been applied, SecurityCoach will automatically sync the Microsoft Teams integration every 12 hours. You can also manually resync your users by following the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 console.
  2. Navigate to SecurityCoach > SetUp.
  3. Click the Microsoft Teams vendor tile.
  4. On the Microsoft Teams Setup page, click the Run User Sync button at the bottom-right side of the User Sync Details section.

Once the new sync is complete, the results will display under the User Sync Details section. If there were any errors, you can click Generate CSV to view more details.

Using the Integration

Once you've uploaded the bot and allowed the SecurityCoach application in Microsoft Teams, you can create real-time coaching campaigns to send SecurityTips to your users. For more information about creating real-time coaching campaigns, see our Real-Time Coaching Campaigns Guide.

To view and manage the Microsoft Teams integration in your KSAT console, navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Delivery Setup > Microsoft Teams. From this page, you can view a list of your teams, verify how many users the bot has been enabled for, send yourself a test message, and more.

Note:The Send Me a Test button will use your set training language for the test message. For more information, see the Training Language section of our Localization Guide.

Deleting the Integration

If needed, you can delete your Microsoft Teams integration from SecurityCoach. To delete the integration, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console.
  2. Navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup.
  3. From the menu on the left side of the page, select Delivery Setup.
  4. Click Microsoft Teams.

  5. On the right side of the page, click Delete Integration.
    Note:Deleting this integration in SecurityCoach will also delete it from your Microsoft Teams admin console.

  6. In the pop-up window that opens, click Confirm. When you click this button, a Microsoft 365 login page will open.

  7. Log in with your Microsoft admin credentials. Once you log in, the integration will be deleted.

articles.name: SecurityCoach Product Manual
articles.title: SecurityCoach Product Manual
articles.body:
SecurityCoach is an add-on product for the KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) console that is available for our Platinum-level and Diamond-level customers to purchase. SecurityCoach can be used to coach your users about their behavior in real time using SecurityTips. You can customize your coaching experience by integrating your vendors, reviewing your detection rules, setting up real-time coaching campaigns, and choosing specific SecurityTip media and notifications to send to your users.

Tip:You can use SecurityTips to warn users about their risky behaviors or to reward users for practicing good security behaviors. For example, if a user successfully reports a simulated phishing test, you can send a SecurityTip to congratulate them for spotting the phishing signs.

Before you can begin monitoring user behavior and coaching your users in real time, you will need to set up SecurityCoach in your KSAT console. To set up SecurityCoach, you must configure your vendor integrations, set up a delivery method for your SecurityTips, review your rule detections, and create a real-time coaching campaign.

To learn more about setting up SecurityCoach, see the subsections below.

Tip:To view a SecurityCoach product demo, see our KnowBe4 Product Demos article.

Configuring Security Vendor Integrations

First, you'll need to set up your third-party vendor integrations in the SecurityCoach > Setup tab of your KSAT console. Once you set up a vendor integration, the vendor's data will be available in SecurityCoach. You can use this data to begin monitoring user behaviors.

For more information about setting up vendor integrations in SecurityCoach, see our Setting Up Integrations article.

Adding a Delivery Method

Email is pre-configured as the default delivery method for SecurityCoach. If you coach your users via email, SecurityTips will be sent to their user email address that is set in the Users tab of your KSAT console.


SecurityCoach also supports integrations with Google Chat, Microsoft Teams, and Slack. If your organization uses any of these platforms for communication, we recommend configuring one as your primary delivery method, so you can coach your users where they communicate most often.

Tip:If Google Chat, Microsoft Teams, or Slack are set as the primary delivery method, email can be used as a backup delivery method.

For more information on setting up delivery methods, see our Configuring Delivery Methods article.

Mapping Users

Mapping your users to identifiers, such as a hostname, helps link user behavior to specific users. User mapping is done automatically for email and web security vendors using the user email addresses set in the Users tab of your KSAT console. You may also need to map additional identifiers for your endpoint security vendors. For example, you may need to map users to their hostnames, usernames, or device IDs.

You can configure mapping rules to automatically map users for you, manually map users by uploading a CSV file, or use a combination of both methods. SecurityCoach also provides mapping recommendations for you to review.

For more information about mapping users, see our Map Users in SecurityCoach article.

Reviewing Rule Detections

SecurityCoach provides system detection rules for each security vendor. Detection rules identify which user behaviors you would like to track using the data provided by your integrated vendors. When you integrate a vendor, these detection rules are enabled automatically, but you can also create custom detection rules for your organization's needs.

We recommend reviewing your top detection rules and prioritizing the user behaviors you want to target with your real-time coaching campaigns. To review your top detection rules, navigate to the Reports subtab of SecurityCoach and click Report for the Detection Rules Report. For more information, see our SecurityCoach Reporting Overview article.

To view all your detection rules, navigate to SecurityCoach > Detection Rules. For more information about detection rules, see our Detection Rules Guide.

Creating a Test Mode Campaign

To test how your real-time coaching campaigns will perform before you begin coaching your users, you can use our Test Mode feature to create a test mode campaign. In a test mode campaign, SecurityCoach detects user behaviors but does not send coaching to your users. You can turn your test mode campaign into a real-time coaching campaign at any time. For more information, see our Working with Test Mode Campaigns article.

Creating a Real-Time Coaching Campaign

Finally, we recommend creating a real-time coaching campaign. Real-time coaching campaigns send SecurityTips to users when user behaviors are detected. SecurityTips can be sent through Slack, Microsoft Teams, Google Chat, or email.

To create a real-time coaching campaign, navigate to the Real-Time Coaching subtab of SecurityCoach. For more information, see our Real-Time Coaching Campaigns Guide article.

SecurityCoach Workflow

The SecurityCoach workflow involves both SecurityCoach and the vendors that you have integrated. For more information, see the workflow list below:

  1. Your integrated vendors monitor user behaviors using email, endpoint, and browser events.
  2. The vendors share those events with SecurityCoach.
  3. SecurityCoach processes this information and determines whether the vendor events match the criteria for any of your detection rules.
  4. If an event matches a detection rule’s criteria, the detection rule is triggered, and the event is added to the responsible user’s events timeline.
  5. If the detection rule is part of a real-time coaching campaign, the user will also receive a SecurityTip to coach their behavior.

SecurityCoach events can also influence your users’ and organization's Risk Score. For more information, see the Security Types section of our SmartRisk Agent™ and Risk Score Guide.

Navigating Your SecurityCoach Product

The SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console includes six subtabs:

  • Dashboard
  • Real-Time Coaching
  • Detection Rules
  • SecurityTips
  • Setup
  • Reports

You can navigate these subtabs to view your SecurityCoach data, create real-time coaching campaigns, review detection rules, preview SecurityTips, set up configurations, view reports, and more. For more information about each of these subtabs, see the subsections below.

Dashboard

When you navigate to the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console, the Dashboard subtab will display automatically. In this subtab, you can read a quick overview of your SecurityCoach data, including charts and summaries.

During your initial setup, the dashboard will also display the SecurityCoach Setup section. This section guides you through the four steps to start your coaching program. After you create a real-time coaching campaign, this section will be replaced with your real-time coaching data.

For more information about the dashboard, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Last 90 days: Your dashboard will display data and activity from the last 90 days by default. However, you can change this date range by clicking on the Last 90 days drop-down list and selecting a different date range.
  2. Notifications: Click the bell icon to view your SecurityCoach notifications.
  3. Real-Time Coaching Summary: This section displays data for your real-time coaching campaigns.
  4. SecurityTips Delivered: This section displays the total number of SecurityTips that have been sent to users.
  5. Users Coached: This section displays the percentage of users who received SecurityTips.
  6. Active Campaigns: This section displays the total number of active real-time coaching campaigns.
  7. Vendor Events Summary: This section displays data for your vendor events.
  8. Total Events: This section displays the number of events from your integrated vendors.
  9. Users with Events: This section displays the number of users with events.
  10. Mapped Events: This section displays the number of events mapped to users. The percentage represents the number of your organization’s events that are mapped.
  11. Unmapped Events: This section displays the number of your organization’s events that aren’t mapped to a user. The percentage represents the number of your organization's events that aren’t mapped.
  12. Top Detection Rules: This chart displays your 10 most common detections.
  13. Top Users by Rule Detections: This section displays the users with the most rule detections.

Real-Time Coaching

You can create and manage real-time coaching campaigns and test mode campaigns by navigating to SecurityCoach > Real-Time Coaching subtab. Real-time coaching campaigns can be used to send SecurityTips to coach users when specific user behaviors are detected. SecurityTips can be sent through Slack, Microsoft Teams, Google Chat, or email.

Note:Your users must be in your KSAT console in order to receive notifications and SecurityTips.

For more information about setting up a real-time coaching campaign, see our Real-Time Coaching Campaigns Guide.


You can create a test mode campaign to see how your real-time coaching campaign will perform before you begin coaching your users. For more information about setting up a test mode campaign, see our Working with Test Mode Campaigns article.

Detection Rules

You can create and manage detection rules in SecurityCoach > Detection Rules. Detection rules identify what user behavior you would like to track from your integrated vendors. These detections will then appear on your users’ timelines. You can also create real-time coaching campaigns to send SecurityTips to users based on these rules.

For more information about creating and managing detection rules, see our Detection Rules Guide.

SecurityTips

The SecurityTips subtab displays the SecurityTip graphics and notification templates you can use in your real-time coaching campaigns. SecurityTips can be used to coach your users about their user behaviors and how to improve their security posture.

You can use our SecurityTip graphics or upload your own. SecurityTips are localized based on the recipient's training language. For more information about custom graphics, see our Upload Custom SecurityTip Graphics article.

To learn more about the SecurityTips subtab and how to use it, see our SecurityTips Guide.

Setup

In the SecurityTips > Setup subtab, you can configure your vendor integrations, map your users, and set up a delivery method for your SecurityTips. The Setup subtab includes the three pages listed below:

  • Security Vendor Integrations: On this page, you can view your active vendor integrations, set up new vendor integrations, and fix broken vendor integrations. For more information about vendor integrations, see our Setting Up Integrations articles.
  • User Mapping Setup: On this page, you can map your users, review mapping recommendations, and view reports related to user mapping. For more information about user mapping, see our Map Users in SecurityCoach article.
  • Delivery Setup: On this page, you can set up and view your delivery methods for SecurityCoach. For more information about setting up delivery channels, see our Configuring Delivery Methods articles.

Reports

The Reports subtab includes reports based on your SecurityCoach security risks, detection rules, and real-time coaching campaigns. The reports are listed below:

  • Detection Rules Report
  • Real-Time Coaching Report
  • Real-Time Coaching Activity Reports
  • Risk Report for Endpoint Security Vendors
  • Risk Report for Email Security Vendors
  • Risk Report for Web Security Vendors
  • Vendor Events Report

Every report, except for the Vendor Events Report, displays data and activity over the last 90 days by default. You can adjust the report view to reflect a different date range by using the drop-down menu at the top-right corner of the specific report.

The Vendor Events Report displays up to 10,000 of the most recent events that occurred over the last 30 days. You can adjust the date range for this report up to the last 30 days using the Date Range drop-down menu.

Note:The Vendor Events Report shows only events that have been linked to detection rules. To include more events in your report, visit the Creating a Custom Detection Rule section of our Detection Rules Guide to create and link detection rules to the events.

For more information about SecurityCoach reports, see our SecurityCoach Reporting Overview.

articles.name: Product Guide Feature Overview
articles.title: Product Guide Feature Overview
articles.body:
You can use our product guide feature overview to learn more about the features we offer and how to use them. As you navigate through our products, product guides may display to provide relevant information about the page you're viewing or to notify you about any product changes. You can also use the Resource Center to search for any guides we have created.

Note: You may need to adjust your pop-up blocker settings. To learn how to access your pop-up blocker settings, see the Adjusting Pop-up Blocker Settings in Your Browser section of the Why Can’t I Open Training in My Browser? article.

Types of Product Guides

There are several types of guides that you may see in our products. The product guides that display will depend on the pages you view and the features you use.

To learn about each type of product guide, see the list below:

  • Banner: Banners display at the top of the page and provide important information, such as new feature announcements and product updates.
  • Lightbox: Lightboxes display in the center of the page and introduce you to a walkthrough or provide information about a feature.

  • Spotlight: Spotlights display next to specific items to prompt you to interact with the item or to provide you with information about the item.

  • Walkthrough: Walkthroughs display anywhere on the page and show you how to complete a task. Typically, walkthroughs are a combination of lightboxes and spotlights.

Navigating Through Product Guides

You can click the buttons in a product guide to navigate through the guide, exit the guide, or learn more about the topic.

For information about the most common buttons in product guides, see the list below:

  • Back: You can click this button to return to the previous step in the guide.
  • Next: You can click this button to continue to the next step in the guide.
  • Learn More: You can click this button to navigate to an article that contains additional information about the topic.
  • Remind Me Later: You can click this button to dismiss a guide. This button will typically display in banners. If you click this button, the guide will display again after a set amount of time, depending on the notification's urgency.
    • For example, an urgent notification may display again in 24 hours. If you would like to access the guide before it displays again, you can search for the guide in our Resource Center. For more information, see the Using the Resource Center section below.
  • X: You can click this button to exit the guide. If you click this button, the guide will not display again.
    • If you would like to access the guide after clicking this button, you can search for the guide in our Resource Center. For more information, see the Using the Resource Center section below.

Using the Resource Center

From the Resource Center, you can view product guides to learn more about our features, search our Knowledge Base, and view release notes.

To access the Resource Center, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to a KnowBe4 product.
  2. At the bottom corner of the page, click the icon for the product you're using. When you click this button, the Resource Center will open.

To learn more about the options available in the Resource Center, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Release Notes: You can select this option to view release notes for the product, such as new feature releases.

  2. Onboarding Guides: You can select this option to view guides that help you get started using the product.
  3. All Guides: You can select this option to view all available guides for the product.
  4. Knowledge Base: You can click this option to quickly search our Knowledge Base for articles or videos related to a specific topic.

articles.name: How to Add and Configure Questions from Questionnaire Templates
articles.title: How to Add and Configure Questions from Questionnaire Templates
articles.body:
In the KCM GRC Vendor Risk Management module, you can create questionnaires to send to the vendors or third parties your organization works with. When you create a questionnaire, you can use your own questions, or you can add questions from our questionnaire templates. Our templates are based on industry standards such as the Standard Information Gathering (SIG) questionnaire and the Consensus Assessment Initiative Questionnaire (CAIQ). Since these standards are familiar to auditors, you can use questions from our templates to expedite your vendor audits.

When you create a questionnaire, you can add a combination of questions from questionnaire templates and custom questions. For general information about creating questionnaires in your platform, see our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article.

To learn how to add and configure questions from questionnaire templates, see the sections below.

Note: The instructions in this article only apply to KCM GRC questionnaire templates. For information about custom questionnaire templates, see the Creating a Custom Questionnaire Template section of our How to Create and Configure Custom Questions in a Questionnaire article.

Adding Questions from a Questionnaire Template

When you create a questionnaire, you can add questions from the questionnaire templates we offer.

To add questions from a questionnaire template to a questionnaire, follow the steps below:

  1. Create a questionnaire. For instructions, see steps 1-4 of the Creating Questionnaires section of our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article.
  2. In the Add Questions From section of the page, click the list button. When you click this button, the questionnaire templates we offer will display on the left side of the Questionnaire Templates window.
  3. Click the drop-down arrow next to a template to view the sections in that template.
  4. Select the check boxes next to the questions you would like to add to your questionnaire. To sort through the questions in the template, you can either navigate through the pages by using the page numbers at the bottom of the window, or you can click through the template sections under the template name.  
    Tip: To add all of the questions in the questionnaire template to your questionnaire, select the check box above the list of questions. Then, click the Select all questions in "[Template Name]" button.
  5. After you finish selecting questions, click the Add button at the bottom of the window.  
Tip: After you have added your questions, you can view them by selecting the All drop-down menu in the Add Questions From section of the page. Then, click the name of the system template you added the questions from.

Configuring Questions from a Questionnaire Template

After you add questions from a questionnaire template to your questionnaire, you will need to configure points for each answer. When your vendors complete the questionnaire, the points that you assign to each question will be used to score their responses.

Your organization can determine a method for measuring the points that you assign to the questions. Each of a vendor's correct or partially-correct answers will contribute to the total score that the vendor receives for the questionnaire.

To configure a questionnaire that you created from a questionnaire template, follow the steps below:

  1. From the navigation panel in your platform, navigate to Vendor Management > Questionnaires.
  2. From the Name column, select the questionnaire that you would like to configure.
  3. In the Questionnaire Versions section of the page, click the Configure button.
  4. Assign points to the questions in your questionnaire. You can either assign the same number of points to all questions or individually assign points to each question. For more information, see the list below:
    Note: The point values must be whole numbers.
    • To assign the same number of points to all questions, enter a point value into the field next to the Set For All button. Then, click the Set For All button.
      Important: If your questionnaire includes questions that use the checkbox answer format, the Set For All feature will also assign this number to the weight for each check box answer option.
    • To individually assign points to a question, click the pencil icon next to the question. Then, enter a number into the Points field and click the check icon.
  5. After you assign points to all questions and you are satisfied with your questionnaire, click the Mark as Configured button. When you click this button, your questionnaire will be in the Configured status.

Before you can send the questionnaire to vendors, the questionnaire will need to be marked as Reviewed. For more information, see the Reviewing and Finalizing Questionnaires section of our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article.

articles.name: Team Dashboard Overview for Admins
articles.title: Team Dashboard Overview for Admins
articles.body:
The Team Dashboard is a customizable dashboard designed for managers to view in their Learner Experience (LX). The default Team Dashboard displays the manager's team, which includes their direct reports. Each manager can also view the Team Dashboard for up to three levels of managers below them in their organization's management hierarchy.

On the dashboard, managers can view the training progress for the users on the selected team. They can also view the status of the users' optional learning, if Optional Learning is enabled in your organization's account. You have the option to include the team’s phishing results and combined Risk Score too. All the data displayed on the Team Dashboard is from the last 12 months.

Note: The Team Dashboard only displays data from active campaigns.

Note: If you are looking for information about your Team Dashboard, see our Team Dashboard Overview for Managers article.

Click the links below to learn how to set up the Team Dashboard feature.

Before You Begin

When users are imported into the KSAT console, user-specific information is typically imported as well. This information includes a Manager field that determines which users are managers and which users report to those managers.

Before enabling Team Dashboards, make sure that the users in your console have managers listed in their user information. You can verify your users’ information by reviewing the Manage Users page in your admin console. To review this information, follow the steps below:

  1. In your KSAT console, navigate to the Users tab.
  2. In the top-right of the Manage Users page, click the gear icon.
  3. From the drop-down menu that opens, select Manager Email.
  4. The Manager Email column will now display in the user list. Review this column to verify that your users have managers listed

Alternatively, you can generate a CSV file of all of your users and their information by clicking the green Generate CSV link at the top of the Manage Users page. For more information, see our Users and Groups article.

If your users do not have managers listed, you can update this information by using one of the methods listed below:

  • If you use a user provisioning integration such as Active Directory or SCIM in your account, you must update your users' manager information directly from your identity provider.
  • If you do not use a user provisioning integration in your account, you can create and import a CSV file to add manager information. For more information about this process, see our How to Import Users with a CSV File article.
    Important: When creating your CSV file, only use the Email and Manager Email column headers.

Enable Team Dashboards

When Team Dashboards are enabled, any user who is listed as another user’s manager will see their Team Dashboard on the Dashboard tab of the LX. To enable and customize your organization’s Team Dashboards, follow the steps below:

  1. From your KnowBe4 admin account, click on your email address at the top-right of the page and select Account Settings.
  2. In your Account Settings, navigate to Training > Learner Experience > Team Dashboard.
  3. Under Team Dashboard, select the Enable Team Dashboard check box.
  4. Once you have selected the Enable Team Dashboard check box, you can customize the Team Dashboards using any of the optional settings listed below:
    1. Limit User Information Shown: By default, the Team Dashboard lists each user with details about their individual contributions to the team’s statistics. To only show aggregated information for the team, turn on the Limit User Information Shown toggle.
    2. Enable Phishing Information: To display the team’s phishing results, select the Enable Phishing Information check box.
    3. Enable Risk Information: To display the team’s current combined Risk Score, select the Enable Risk Information check box.
  5. Click the Save Changes button at the bottom of the page.

Notify Managers

Once you enable the Team Dashboard, we recommend that you send a message to managers to notify them about their new dashboards.

For example, you can copy and paste the message below to send to managers. Before you send the message, make sure that it applies to your organization. You can also customize the message by adding or removing information.

Tip:To send a message to managers, you can use the User Messaging feature. For more information, see our User Messaging Guide.

Hi all,

When you log in to your KnowBe4 training console, you may notice that the Dashboard tab has changed. From this tab, you can now view information about your direct reports, including their training progress, phishing results, and combined Team Risk Score.

For more information, see KnowBe4's Learner Support: Team Dashboard Overview for Managers article. We hope you enjoy this new feature.

Thank you,

[[your name]]

articles.name: How to Create and Manage Policy Campaigns
articles.title: How to Create and Manage Policy Campaigns
articles.body:
In the Policy Management module of your KCM GRC platform, you can create policy campaigns to send policies to your users. When your users receive the policies in their email, they can read and acknowledge them. Then, as your users acknowledge the policies, you can monitor your campaign progress. 

See the sections below to learn how to create and manage policy campaigns. For general information about the Policy Management module, see our Policy Management Module Guide. 

Creating Campaigns

When you create a campaign, you can select the policy or policies that you would like to assign to your users. You can also set campaign notifications to prompt your users to acknowledge the policies. 

Important:Before you create a campaign, you will need to add policy management users to policy management groups. To learn how to create policy management users and groups, see our How to Add Users and Groups to the Policy Management Module. 

To create a policy campaign, follow the steps below:

  1. From the navigation panel, navigate to Policy Management > Campaigns.
  2. In the top-right corner of the page, click the Create Campaign button.
  3. Fill out the fields on the Create a New Campaign page. For more information about these fields, see the list below:
    Note:We recommend that you avoid including the < and > special characters in these fields.

    1. Name: Enter a name for your campaign. This name will be included in any email notifications that you set up for this campaign.
    2. Start Date: Click this field to open a calendar where you can select a start date for your campaign. 
    3. Start Time: Enter a start time into the field, or click the clock icon to select a start time for your campaign.
      Note:You must select a start time that is at least 15 minutes after the time that you create the campaign.
    4. Time Zone: From the drop-down menu, select a time zone for your campaign's start time.
    5. End Campaign At: Select a type of end date for the campaign. To learn about each type of end date, see the list below:
      • Specify Date: Select this option to set a specific end date for the campaign. When you select this option, End Date and End Time fields will appear. In these fields, you can select the date and time that you would like for your campaign to end on. 
      • Relative Duration: Select this option to set a deadline based on when users are enrolled in the campaign. When you select this option, a Relative Duration field will appear. In this field, you can select the amount of time that users will have to acknowledge the policy or policies after you add the users to the campaign. The campaign notifications that you set up will be sent to users based on when they are enrolled in the campaign.
      • No End Date: Select this option to create the campaign without an end date. If you would like to encourage your users to promptly acknowledge your organization's policies, we do not recommend that you select this option.
    6. Link Expiration: Select the amount of time that users can click the policy link before the link expires. We recommend that you select a time length that corresponds with the type of end date you selected for this campaign. For more information about the recommended link expirations, see the list below:
      • Specify Date: We recommend that you select a link expiration that comes before the campaign's end date because policy acknowledgments will not be recorded after the campaign ends.
      • Relative Duration: We recommend that you select a link expiration that is the same length of time as the relative duration. When users receive campaign notifications for campaigns with Relative Duration selected, the notifications will instruct the users to acknowledge the policy before the link expiration date.
      • No End Date: Because this campaign does not have an end date, you can select any link expiration. When your users receive campaign notifications for the campaign, the notifications will instruct the users to acknowledge the policy before the link expiration date.
    7. Select Campaign Policy(ies): From the drop-down menu, select the policy or policies that you would like for your users to acknowledge.
    8. Select Campaign Group(s): From the drop-down menu, select the user groups that you would like to include in the campaign. For example, if your organization uses policies that only apply to specific job roles, you may want to create role-based user groups and policy campaigns. To learn more about user groups, see the Creating Policy Management Groups section of our How to Add Users and Groups to the Policy Management Module article. 
    9. Automatically enroll users that are added in the future: Select this check box if you would like to automatically enroll users as they are added to the groups that are included in the campaign.
    10. Notifications: Click the + button to expand this menu. Then, select the types of notifications that you would like to include in the campaign. To learn about the types of campaign notifications that you can select, see the Selecting Policy Campaign Notifications section below.
      Important:We recommend that you always include campaign notifications in a campaign. Without campaign notifications, your users will not receive the campaign emails that allow them to access your policies. 
      Note: If a user is enrolled in multiple campaigns at one time, they may receive two or more campaign notifications in one KCM GRC email. For more information, see the Policy Campaign Notifications section of our Email Notifications and the Email Digest article.

Selecting Policy Campaign Notifications

When you create a campaign, you can select from six types of campaign notifications to send to your users or the campaign owner. 

To learn about the types of campaign notifications you can include in a campaign, see the list below: 

  • On Campaign Start (User): When the campaign starts, an email will be sent to all users who are included in the campaign.
  • Before Acknowledgement Due (User): Before the campaign's due date, an email will be sent to all users who are included in the campaign that have not acknowledged the policies yet. If you select this option, a Number of Days field will appear. In this field, you can enter the number of days before the due date that you would like for the notification email to send. You can add multiple instances of this type of notification by entering a different number in the Number of Days field for each instance.
  • On Campaign Start (Campaign Owner): When the campaign starts, an email will be sent to notify the creator of the campaign that the campaign has started. This notification will include the campaign's start date and start time.
  • Before Campaign End (Campaign Owner): Before the campaign's end date, an email will be sent to notify the creator of the campaign that the campaign is ending in a number of days. If you select this option, a Number of Days field will appear. In this field, you can enter the number of days before the due date that you would like for the notification email to send.
  • On Campaign Completion (Campaign Owner): When the campaign ends, an email will be sent to notify the creator of the campaign that the campaign has ended. This notification will include a link to sign in to KCM GRC and view the campaign.
    Note: If the campaign has a Relative Duration end date, you will not be able to select this type of notification.
  • On Campaign Enrollment (User): After the campaign starts, an email will be sent to any users that are added to the groups that are included in the campaign. This notification will include links to all of the policies that are included in the campaign.
    Note:You will only be able to select this type of notification for campaigns with Relative Duration and No End Date end dates. 

Monitoring and Managing Policy Campaigns

After your policy campaign starts, you can monitor the campaign's progress to see which users have acknowledged your policies.

To view a campaign's progress, follow the instructions below:

  1. Navigate to Policy Management > Campaigns.
  2. Select a campaign's name from the list of campaigns. When you select a campaign, you will be taken to the campaign's View Campaign page.
  3. Select the Overview, Users, and Members tabs to view details about the campaign.

To learn about the Overview, Users, and Members tabs of the View Campaign page, see the subsections below. 

Overview Tab

From the Overview tab, you can view information about the campaign’s progress. For more information about this tab, see the list below:

  1. Progress: View the number of policies that users who are included in the campaign have acknowledged. 
  2. Percentage: View the percentage of policies that users who are included in the campaign have acknowledged.
  3. User Acknowledgement Activity: View the progress of your users' policy acknowledgments. This graph will show a daily, weekly, or monthly view, depending on how far apart the campaign's start date and end date are. 
  4. Nudge Users: Click this button to automatically send a reminder email to all enrolled users who have not acknowledged the required policies. After you click the Nudge Users button, an alert will appear to report the number of users that were sent the reminder email. 
  5. Update Campaign: Click this button to edit the campaign's details. 
  6. Campaign Details: View details about the campaign, such as the status, enrolled groups, and scheduled notifications.

Users Tab

From the Users tab, you can view a breakdown of the users who are enrolled in the campaign. For more information about this tab, see the list below: 

  1. Search: Use this search bar to search for users who have been enrolled in the campaign. 
  2. First Name, Last Name, Email: View each users first name, last name, and email address.
  3. Plus or minus: Click this button to expand or minimize a user's progress for each policy in the campaign. 
  4. Force Acknowledgement for Selected: Click this button to mark the policy as acknowledged for any users that you have selected on this page. 

Members Tab

From the Members tab, you can view a list of the users in your account who currently have access to view or edit the policy campaign. This tab displays each user's name, email address, and user role.

articles.name: Glossary of Policy Management Terms
articles.title: Glossary of Policy Management Terms
articles.body:
This glossary contains terms that will help you use the Policy Management module of your KCM GRC platform. For general information about the Policy Management module, see our Policy Management Module Guide. 

Campaigns

A campaign is a feature in your platform that you can use to assign policies to your users. You can select the policies and user groups that are included in a campaign. You can also set up notifications to prompt your users to acknowledge the campaign policies. Then, you can monitor the progress of each campaign from the View Campaign page.

For more information about creating and managing campaigns in the Policy Management module, see our How to Create and Manage Policy Campaigns article. 

Campaign Notifications

Campaign notifications notify users or the campaign owner as the campaign progresses. When you create or update a campaign, you can select the types of notifications that a campaign sends.

The types of campaign notifications are listed below.

  • On Campaign Start (User)
  • Before Acknowledgement Due (User)
  • On Campaign Start (Campaign Owner)
  • Before Campaign End (Campaign Owner)
  • On Campaign Completion (Campaign Owner)

To learn more about campaign notifications, see the Selecting Policy Notifications section of our How to Create and Manage Policy Campaigns article.

Campaign Owner

A campaign owner is the user who creates the campaign. Depending on the notification types that the campaign owner selects for a campaign, they can receive notifications when the campaign starts, completes, and ends.

Policies

A policy is an agreement, such as a document or standard, that users in your organization must follow. In your platform, you can upload or add a link to a policy that you will use for a campaign. 

Note:KCM GRC offers policy templates that you can download and customize for your organization. To learn more about the policy templates that we offer, see our Policy Templates article. 

For more information about using policies in the Policy Management module, see the Step Two: Add Policies section of our Policy Management Module Guide.

Policy Management Groups

Policy Management Groups are groups that you create and assign Policy Management Users to. You can create Policy Management Groups from the Policy Management Users & Groups page. Before you can send policies to Policy Management Users, you must assign them to a Policy Management Group. 

For more information about Policy Management Groups, see our How to Add Users and Groups to the Policy Management Module article.

Policy Management Reports

Policy Management Reports show the progress of each campaign in your platform. The reports are automatically created when a user creates a campaign. You can view Policy Management Reports from the Reports tab of the navigation panel. 

For more information about Policy Management Reports, see the Policy Management Reports section of our Metrics Reporting Guide article. 

Policy Management Users

Policy Management Users are users that you create in the Policy Management module of your platform. When you create Policy Management Users, they are not assigned licenses to KCM GRC because they are not KCM GRC users. You can add Policy Management Users to Policy Management Groups, and you can assign Policy Management Groups to policy campaigns. Then, Policy Management Users can view and acknowledge policies. 

For more information about Policy Management Users, see our How to Add Users and Groups to the Policy Management Module article.

Policy Template

A policy template is a policy that you can download and customize from your platform. Then, you can add the customized policy to a campaign. Each policy template incorporates controls from the National Institute of Security and Technology.

KCM GRC policy templates cover security and privacy topics. See the list below for examples of the policy templates that KCM GRC offers.

  • Media Protection Policy
  • Mobile Device Policy
  • Risk Assessment and Management Policy

For more information about policy templates, see our Policy Templates article.

articles.name: Glossary of Vendor Risk Management Terms
articles.title: Glossary of Vendor Risk Management Terms
articles.body:
This glossary contains terms that will help you use the Vendor Risk Management module in your KCM GRC platform. For general information about the Vendor Risk Management module, please see our Vendor Risk Management Module Guide article. 

Questionnaires

A questionnaire is a set of questions that you can create to assess your vendors. You can use questionnaires to determine whether you want to work with a vendor.

For more information about questionnaires, see our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article. 

Custom Questions

A custom question is a question that you can create and add to questionnaires. You can create individual custom questions in the questionnaire builder, or you can import a set of questions into the questionnaire builder. 

For more information about custom questions, see our How to Use Custom Questions in Questionnaires article. 

Questionnaire Status

Questionnaire statuses can help you monitor the progress of your questionnaires as you prepare the questionnaires for your vendors.

See the list below for details about each questionnaire status. 

  • Configured: The questionnaire is fully set up and ready for review. Answer options, correct answers, and points are all set. When you create a questionnaire, you can set this status by clicking the Mark as Configured button. 
  • Not Configured: The questionnaire is not fully set up. You must set answer options, correct answers, and points before you can mark the questionnaire as configured.
  • Reviewed: The questionnaire is fully set up, and a Vendor Administrator or an Account Administrator has reviewed it. When the Vendor Administrator or Account Administrator reviews a configured questionnaire, they can set this status by clicking the Mark as Reviewed button. Then, you can send the questionnaire to your vendors. 

For more information about marking the questionnaires as configured and reviewed, see our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article. 

Vendors

A vendor is any third-party organization that your organization works with. You can add vendors to the Vendor Risk Management module to send them questionnaire assessments. 

Qualifying Questions

Qualifying questions are questions that you can use to assess the level of risk associated with each vendor in your platform. You can view or answer the qualifying questions by navigating to a vendor's Vendor Details page. 

For more information about qualifying questions, see the Qualifying Questions section of our How to Create and Manage Vendor Profiles article. 

Vendor Contact

A vendor contact is a person from the vendor's organization who you will be working with for questionnaire assessments. On the Vendor Details page, you can provide contact information for one or more vendor contacts to give them access to questionnaires. However, the vendor contact who is listed in the Contact Email field is the only person who will receive email notifications about questionnaires.

For more information about adding vendor contacts, see the Organization Contact Details section of our How to Create and Manage Vendor Profiles article. 

Vendor Dashboard

The Vendor Dashboard provides an overview of the potential risk that your vendors pose for your organization, as well as an overview of your organization's questionnaires and questionnaire issues.

For more information about the Vendor Dashboard, see our How to Use the Vendor Dashboard article. 

Vendor Issue

You can create a vendor issue when you review a vendor’s questionnaire responses and want to request additional information or to address a concern.

For more information about vendor issues, see the Creating Issues section of our How to Review Questionnaires and Create Issues article. 

Vendor Profile

A vendor profile includes any information about a vendor that administrators have added to your account. Administrators can create vendor profiles by entering information into the Vendor Details page, or they can create vendor profiles by importing a CSV file.

For more information about vendor profiles, see our How to Create and Manage Vendor Profiles article.

Vendor Score

A vendor score is the average score of all questionnaires that the vendor has completed. You can use vendor scores to determine whether you need to continue assessing a vendor or whether you need to request additional information from a vendor. Generally, higher scores indicate that the vendor has a lower risk level, and lower scores indicate that the vendor has a higher risk level. 

For more information about the vendor score, see the Working With Vendor Profiles section of our How to Create and Manage Vendor Profiles article. 

Vendor Status

Vendor statuses can indicate your organization's involvement with a vendor. You can use these statuses to organize the vendors in your platform.

See the list below for details about each vendor status. 

  • Active: You may change the vendor status to Active if your organization is currently working with the vendor. You can send the vendor questionnaires if the vendor’s status is Active.
  • Inactive: You may change the vendor status to Inactive if your organization is not currently working with the vendor.
  • Incomplete: When you import a vendor, the vendor’s status defaults to Incomplete. You may also change the vendor status to Incomplete as a reminder to add information to the vendor profile.
  • Pending Approval: When you create a new vendor, the vendor’s status defaults to Pending Approval. You can also manually set this status before deciding whether you want to work with a vendor. You can send the vendor questionnaires if the vendor’s status is Pending Approval.
  • Rejected: You may use this status after you receive a vendor’s questionnaire and decide not to work with the vendor.

Vendor User

A vendor user is a user role that only has access to questionnaires, issues, and files that KCM GRC administrators have added to the Attachments tab of the Vendor Details page. Vendor users do not have access to any other information in your organization's account, and they do not count against your licensed seat count for KCM GRC. To access questionnaires, vendor users must sign in to a separate portal that is associated with your account. You can add vendor users from the Contacts tab of the Vendor Details page.

For more information about creating vendor users, see the Adding User Accounts for Vendor Contacts section of our How to Create and Manage Vendor Profiles article.

articles.name: Security Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)
articles.title: Security Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)
articles.body:
1. How do we prevent customers from accessing other customers' data?

We leverage logical database separation to ensure customer privacy and confidentiality in our multi-tenant architecture. These strict privacy controls exist in our application code to ensure data privacy and prevent one customer from accessing another customer's data. This is done using unique account identifiers which attribute each user to a specific account. We have many unit and integration tests in place to ensure these privacy controls work as intended. We run these tests every time our codebase is updated. Even one single test failure will prevent new code from being shipped to production.

 

2. How often do we conduct backups?

 Our backup and recovery infrastructure is hosted and utilizes the combination of Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) and Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS), which provides resizable database capacity with scalable and efficient data storage infrastructure. The Amazon RDS service is set to back up the production database every day, maintains 35 days of backups, and stores the encrypted database backups in a high-availability data storage location. The Amazon RDS service also allows for a point-in-time restoration of the database for any point in time going back two weeks. Old copies of backups are deleted in accordance with our data retention schedule.

 

3. What is KnowBe4's RPO (Recovery Point Objective) and RTO (Recovery Time Objective)?    

Our RPO is a few minutes to hours but will be no later than 72 hours. Our RTO is 72 hours. 

 

4. What is KnowBe4's change control/management procedure? 

We have implemented a formal change management process that allows staff to request, manage, approve, and control changes that modify services or systems within our environments. The change control process is designed to enforce key development controls each time a change is made to the software, including development and emergency changes. The change management process begins with the identification of what needs to be changed; recording and classification of the change; and continues with the review, approval, test, and staging for implementation of the change. Once implementation has been completed, measured, and reported, the change process is complete.

    

5. Is production data used in your test environment? 

Production data is not copied to test environments. We have a daily process that anonymizes our entire production database. This process is overseen by our data privacy and infosec teams. This anonymized database includes anonymized customer account details, such as a customer's address, domain, company name, personal data, and other confidential information. This anonymized database is used for testing as necessary. We refresh this database daily so that when account data is deleted or purged, the account data is also purged from the anonymized database.

    

6. How is KnowBe4 employee access managed and monitored? 

KnowBe4 follows the principle of least privilege and role-based access for its employees. All employee access is logged and monitored.

    

7. What kind of data is collected or processed by Knowbe4?

KSAT

Data Collected Directly From Customer: First Name, Last Name, Manager First Name, Manager Last Name, Business Phone Number, Business Email Address, Mobile Phone Number, Employee Title, Employee Department, IP Address, Browser Information

 

Generated Information: Phishing Campaign Results and Metrics, Security Awareness Training Results, Risk Score
PhishER Email information submitted by customer
KCM GRC Email address, browser information, strictly necessary cookie information, and information customers upload into the console (audit reports, compliance reports, etc.)

 

8. Where can I find a list of your sub-processors? 

A list of our sub-processors can be found here.

 

9. How does KnowBe4 ensure the availability of its product? 

Our systems run in the cloud and do not run their own routers, load balancers, DNS servers, or virtual systems. Except for a few data sub-processors, services, and data, data is hosted primarily in Amazon AWS data centers. For US-based customers and customers wanting to keep their data residing in the US, we have systems in AWS data centers located in the US region in North Virginia. For customers based in the EU/EEA (including UK and Switzerland), we have systems located in AWS data centers that store production data in DC Dublin, Ireland with a failover in DC Frankfurt. However, a few data sub-processors will process a limited subset of data in the United States. A full accounting of data processing locations can be found in our sub-processor listing.

Our systems are built taking both business continuity and disaster recovery into consideration. Our IT infrastructure, including systems and databases, is spread across multiple Amazon AWS data centers (availability zones) for both the EU and US regions for continuity purposes. Systems are within our own virtual private cloud (VPC) with network access control lists (ACLs) to prevent unauthorized requests from gaining access to the internal network.

We use the AWS Fargate platform as a service. AWS Fargate is a serverless computer engine for Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) that allows KnowBe4 to run containers without having to provision, configure, and scale clusters of virtual machines (VMs). AWS Fargate manages the underlying infrastructure and clusters. It also automatically scales the application based on demand. AWS Fargate eliminates the need to scale, monitor, patch, and secure EC2 instances.

Data communication between our backend systems and our customers' backend systems is encrypted, which protects data in transit. Data is held in an encrypted Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS), which provides for availability and data durability. Storage is provided by encrypted Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3) buckets dedicated to KnowBe4. Encryption is enabled to protect data at rest.

 

10. How does KnowBe4 ensure the confidentiality of our data? 

Our internal network is protected from public internet traffic via stateful inspection firewalls provided by Amazon AWS. A security group acts as a firewall and controls the traffic allowed into a group of instances. For each security group, custom rules are added that govern the allowed inbound traffic to instances in the group. All other inbound traffic is denied.

Encrypted communication is utilized to protect remote internet sessions to our applications and internal network. Encryption is used to ensure the privacy and integrity of the data being passed over the public network.

All data is transmitted over secure channels. This includes access to the Service Provider Training console website, information sent to third parties for processing, and logging. Data that is sent between the web server and the database is done within a virtual private cloud within AWS.

Data sent between our applications and our customers' applications is forced through at minimum HTTPS TLS 1.2 (it will default to the highest level of TLS available) connection using modern ciphers. The database instance is encrypted with the AES256 encryption standard.

 

11. What's your data retention policy? 

You can find our data retention policy here.

 

12. Will KnowBe4 sign a Business Associate Addendum as described in HIPAA regulations? 

Business associate addendums are required for organizations that process PHI on behalf of a covered entity. Our BAA is available at https://www.knowbe4.com/business-associate-agreement and forms part of our Terms of Service or other separately signed agreement, such as a Master Services Agreement (“MSA”), in place between Customers and KnowBe4 covering Customer’s use of KnowBe4’s Services (“Agreement”), where applicable.

 

12. Is KnowBe4 HIPAA certified? 

No and currently no HIPAA currently exists for cloud service providers. Regardless of HIPAA applicability, KnowBe4 aligns its information security program with FedRAMP, NIST 800-53, and ISO 27001 requirements.

 

13. How are customers able to verify the location their data is stored/what the location of their console is?

After logging into their console, customers are able to view the URL and verify where their console is stored across KnowBe4’s AWS location offerings. The table below provides information on the console URL and corresponding AWS storage location:

 

URL starts with Storage location
training.knowbe4.com United States (AWS US-East-1)
eu.knowbe4.com Europe (AWS EU-West-1)
uk.knowbe4.com United Kingdom (AWS EU-West-2)
de.knowbe4.com Germany (AWS EU-Central-1)
ca.knowbe4.com Canada (AWS Central)

articles.name: Glossary of Risk Management Terms
articles.title: Glossary of Risk Management Terms
articles.body:
This glossary contains terms that will help you use the Risk Management module of your KCM GRC platform. For general information about the Risk Management module, see our Risk Management Module Guide article. 

Controls

In the Risk Management module, you can use controls to document the preventative measures that your organization uses to mitigate potential risks. You can create new controls for your risks, or if your organization has already added relevant controls to your platform, you can map those controls to the risks in the Risk Register. For the full definition of controls, see Controls in our Glossary of Compliance Terms.

To learn how to use controls in the Risk Management module, see our How to Create and Map Risk Controls article.

Risk

A risk is a potential threat to your organization. The purpose of the Risk Management module is for you to identify, assess, monitor, and mitigate risks. You can add risks to your Risk Register by using the Risk Wizard, creating custom risks, and importing custom risks. When you create custom risks, you can assign an impact, a likelihood, a status, and a tag to the risks. You can also add additional details to risks, including a description, a category, consequences, and an affected asset. For more information about the Risk Management module, see our Risk Management Module Guide. 

The bullet points below are examples of risks.

  • Exploit Known Vulnerabilities in Mobile Systems
  • Craft Spear Phishing Attacks
  • Conduct Physical Attacks on Organizational Facilities

Risk Categories

Risk categories group risks by the area that a risk would affect if it occurred. By default, the Risk Register has six categories, but you can also add custom categories. The default categories are Business & Strategic, Environmental & Natural, Financial, Operational & Infrastructure, Compliance, and Custom.

For more information about risk categories, see the Risk Categories and Subcategories section of our How to Use Your Risk Register article.

Risk Status

Risk statuses describe the current state of a risk and what efforts your organization can make to manage the risk. The risk statuses are Acceptance, Avoidance, Mitigation, Transfer, Triggered, Closed, and Other. 

For more information about risk statuses, see the Creating Individual Risks section of our How to Use Your Risk Register article. 

Risk Tags

Risk tags can help you categorize and find your risks. For example, you can categorize your risks by location if you have different risks in different facilities. Then, you can filter your Risk Register by tag to focus on one or more locations. When you create or update a risk, you can create a new risk tag or select an existing risk tag.

For more information about risk tags, see the Creating Individual Risks section of our How to Use Your Risk Register article. 

Risk Dashboard

The Risk Dashboard provides an overview of the risks in your Risk Register. You can view your Risk Dashboard to monitor your risks by tag, category, and score.

For more information about the Risk Dashboard, see our How to Use the Risk Dashboard article. 

Risk Likelihood and Impact

The Likelihood and Impact can help you estimate the threat that a risk poses for your organization. You can also use the Likelihood and Impact to compare and prioritize risks. You can assign a Likelihood and Impact when you create a new risk. 

For more information about the Likelihood and Impact, see the Risk Likelihood and Impact section of our Risk Management Module Guide.

Risk Likelihood

The Likelihood represents the probability that a risk will impact your organization. The Likelihood levels are Rare, Unlikely, Reasonably Possible, Likely, and Almost Certain. 

Risk Impact

The Impact represents the potential damage that a risk may cause for your organization. The Impact levels are Low, Minor, Moderate, Major, and Catastrophic.

Risk Register

The Risk Register stores all risks that your organization has added to the Risk Management module. We recommend that you add risks to the Risk Register with the Risk Wizard, but you can also import risks in bulk and create risks individually. The Risk Register organizes your risks by category.

For more information about the Risk Register, see our How to Use Your Risk Register article.  

Risk Templates

A risk template is either a risk that KnowBe4 provides or a custom risk that you import into your platform. You can use risk templates to quickly add risks to your Risk Register.

For more information about using risk templates in your platform, see our How to Use the Risk Templates Tab article.

Risk Scores

Risk scores can help you estimate the severity of a risk before and after you make efforts to mitigate the risk. You can assign risk scores to assess and prioritize your risks. 

Inherent Risk Score

The Inherent Risk Score measures the severity of a risk. The score is calculated by multiplying the Likelihood and the Impact. You assign the Inherent Risk Score to risks in your Risk Register.

For more information about the Inherent Risk Score, see the Inherent Risk Score section of our Risk Scoring Guide. 

Residual Risk Score

The Residual Risk Score measures the remaining severity of a risk after considering the controls that are associated with the risk. This score is automatically calculated by subtracting the Treatment Score from the Inherent Risk Score. You can view the Residual Risk Score from the View Risk page. 

For more information about the Residual Risk Score, see the Residual Risk Score section of our Risk Scoring Guide. 

Risk Treatment Score

The Risk Treatment Score measures how well a control prevents or mitigates a risk. You can set this score for controls in your account. The Risk Treatment Score is also referred to as Treatment Score in the platform. You must map a risk to a control before you can add a Treatment Score to the control. After you add a Treatment Score to the control, the score will appear on the View Control page.

For more information about the Risk Treatment Score, see the Treatment Score section of our Risk Scoring Guide. 

Risk Wizard

The Risk Wizard is a tool that can help you identify risks and add risks to your platform. We recommend that you use the Risk Wizard if your organization has not established a risk management program yet. KnowBe4 provides the risks in the Risk Wizard, which all come from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Special Publication 800-30, Guide for Conducting Risk Assessments.

For more information about the Risk Wizard, see our How to Use the Risk Wizard article for more information.

articles.name: Ignore IP Range Guide
articles.title: Ignore IP Range Guide
articles.body:
Note: Before you use the IP Ignore List, we advise you to check that KnowBe4's IP addresses are all properly whitelisted. Ignoring IP addresses can produce false negatives and skew your results. See our Whitelisting Data and Anti-Spam Filtering Information article for more information. Please proceed with caution.

The IP Ignore List feature allows you to block an individual IP address or a range of IP addresses to prevent false-positive phishing test failures. Using the IP Ignore List helps ensure that the data provided from your phishing campaigns are accurate. See below for more information on how to use the IP Ignore List.

Accessing the IP Ignore List

To see your account’s IP Ignore List, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account.
  2. Click the Phishing tab.
  3. Click the Ignore IP Ranges subtab.

From this page, you can ignore IP addresses and see all of the IP addresses that are blocked on your account. You can also remove any failures that came from a specific IP address. To ignore an IP address or range of IP addresses, click + Create IP Range. You can ignore up to 50 IP addresses or 50 IP address ranges.

Important:Removing failures from a specific IP address will result in all associated campaign failures except for Data Entered and Replies to be removed.

Ignoring IP Addresses

Once you know how to access your IP Ignore List, it is important to know what signs to look out for in phishing campaigns to effectively use this feature. You can monitor campaign failures from specific Ignored IPs by clicking on them in the list.

When deleting campaign failures, you will be prompted to make sure you want to delete campaign failures, as they will change your phishing data.

If your organization notices that false positives are coming from a particular IP address or a range of IP addresses, you should add these IP addresses to your IP Ignore List. Once you ignore an IP address, any failures that come from the IP address will not be recorded in your campaign statistics. 

Note:Campaign-specific landing pages may not display after campaign failures if accessed from an ignored IP address.

articles.name: Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB) Guide
articles.title: Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB) Guide
articles.body:
Your organization may have recently installed the Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB). In this article, you will learn how this tool works and how you can use it to help keep your organization safe from malicious phishing emails.

When to Use the PAB

You should select the PAB anytime you suspect that you have received a phishing email or any potentially dangerous email. The emails you report may also be forwarded to a designated contact within your organization for analysis.

How to Use the PAB

You can use the PAB icon to report any email as a phishing email, but you cannot use the PAB to report multiple emails at once. You should report each potential phishing email individually. However, if you report an email that has multiple emails associated with it, all of the associated emails will be reported as well.

Gmail Inbox

To use the PAB add-on in your Gmail inbox, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Gmail account on your web browser.
  2. Open the email that you would like to report.
  3. Open the add-on menu on the right side of your Google inbox and select the phish hook icon to open the PAB add-on.

  4. (Optional) You can also add comments and select a disposition to provide more information about the email.

  5. Select the blue Phish Alert button to report the email.

  6. Once the confirmation message appears, select the back arrow to go back to your inbox. The reported email will be moved to the Trash folder.
    Note:If you're viewing an email in split pane mode, the back arrow is not available. You can change your Gmail inbox settings to make the back arrow visible. You can also select Inbox or your browser's back arrow to go back to your inbox.

Gmail Mobile

To use the PAB add-on from the Gmail app on your mobile device, follow the instructions below.

  1. Log in to the Gmail app on your mobile device.
  2. Open the email that you would like to report.
  3. Scroll to the bottom of the screen and locate the available add-ons section.
  4. From the add-ons section, select the phish hook icon and scroll down to the bottom of the screen to access the PAB.

  5. Select the blue Report button to report the email.

  6. If enabled, you will see a confirmation message, and the email will be moved to your Trash folder.

  7. Select the back arrow to return to your inbox.

Reason to Use the PAB

Reporting emails will help your organization stay safe. Because the potential phishing emails you report are sent to your organization for analysis, your organization will be aware of which phishing attacks are able to reach their users' inboxes. Once everyone is aware of possible vulnerabilities, they can better defend against cyber attacks. You are an important part of the process of keeping your organization safe from cybercriminals. Stop, look, and think!
